case_vignette: A man, aged 68 years, with no known history of atopy presents with a 4-month history of an itchy and burning rash on the legs that has been recurring every winter for the past 3 years! He notes that he had dry skin at baseline and did not use emollients, but he did try hydrocortisone 1% cream without improvement! Examination revealed ovoid, erythematous, well-marginated plaques on the lower legs and dorsal feet with variable scaling and focal weeping and crusting! There were no nail changes, and the rest of his skin examination was notable only for xerosis!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing an itchy and burning rash on my legs that keeps coming back every winter.
Do you notice any specific triggers related to the onset of the rash each winter, such as exposure to certain materials or changes in your skincare routine?
No, I don't notice any specific triggers related to the onset of the rash each winter.
Have you been diagnosed with any skin conditions in the past or taken any medications for this recurring issue?
I haven't been diagnosed with any skin conditions in the past, and I have tried using hydrocortisone 1% cream, but it didn't improve my symptoms.
Does the rash improve or worsen with changes in temperature or humidity?
The rash recurs every winter, suggesting it might be influenced by the colder and possibly drier conditions during that season.
Does anyone else in your family have similar symptoms or a history of skin conditions?
No, no one else in my family has similar symptoms or a history of skin conditions.
Final Diagnosis: Winter eczema (also known as asteatotic eczema)

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have an itchy and burning rash on my legs that has recurred every winter for the past 3 years.
Is there any noticeable trigger or situation that aggravates the itching and burning sensation?
The itching and burning sensation occurs every winter.

No, the rash is only on my lower legs and the tops of my feet.

Yes, the rashes have red, well-defined patches with some areas that are scaly, and there are some spots that are moist and crusty.

No, I have no known history of allergies or skin conditions.
Have you taken any medication for this condition, and if so, did it provide relief?
I tried using hydrocortisone 1% cream, but it didn't improve my condition.
Final Diagnosis: Eczema (winter eczema/seasonal dermatitis)
